Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Accurate cosmology with strong gravitational lens time delays
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this collaborative project is to improve the current measurement of cosmological quantities, in particular the Hubble constant and the Dark Energy component, using time delay measurements from strong gravitational lenses acting upon quasars. This includes analysis of already taken data, as well as the anticipated discovery of approximately 50 new lenses. Gravitational time delays are not only independent of other methods but are also a very cost effective probe, requiring just a few hours on an 8-10m telescope for modeling the lens, and subsequent monitoring on 1m class telescopes.

Broader impacts of the work include training of graduate students and postdoctoral researchers. At the K-12 level, Dr. Treu collaborates with the Santa Barbara Museum of Natural history (SBMNH) and Las Cumbres Observatories GlobalTelescope Network to organize public lectures, and establish an astronomy curriculum at the UC-operated Sedgwick Natural Reserve. Similarly, Dr. Fassnacht has developed a month-long course for high-school students on the Davis campus as part of the UC COSMOS program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The acceleration of the universe is one of the most profound mysteries in physics. Understanding its origin may lead to a rethinking of the standard paradigm of the cosmological model based on general relativity and cold dark matter. Our team has demonstrated that gravitational lenses with time delays can provide precise and accurate measurements of the expansion rate of the universe and thus, in combination with other probes, of the nature of dark energy. We have published a measurement of the expansion rate of the universe with 3.8% precision, comparable and independent of the current best measurements from other techniques. The precision of the method is limited by the small number of known instrinsically rare systems. Therefore we carried out a major campaign to discover new lensed quasars, and we have already discovered, in collaboration with our colleagues, more than 50 systems, including 15 extremely rare quadruply imaged systems. We also demonstrated new methods and techniques to improve the method even further and carried out tests of systematic uncertainties.

Broader Impact

The PIs have developed a comprehensive educational/public outreach component, aimed at communicating both the content of our research as well as the importance and a real understanding of the scientific method. The PI has developed new innovative general education courses, including "Physics of sustainable energy" at UCLA. The co-PI has developed a month-long course for high-school students on the Davis campus as part of the UC COSMOS program. Several undergraduate students have been mentored and introduced to scientific research as part of this grant, including two students from under-represented minorites through the CALBRIDGE program. Two postdocs and six graduate students have been trained in cutting edge data analysis and in the use of the most powerful telescopes. In parallel with the human effort, the PIs are will continue their efforts to develop new instrumentation for the study of dark energy, especially based on adaptive optics.
